utterances: And one of the analyses of the Roberts nom--the Miers nomination was the president chose not to have that kind of fight.
He didn't want one.
Either he judged himself too politically weak to have one or he didn't have--whatever.
Now he's back to where he was.
Is he willing to have that kind of fight with Democrats?
And you heard Dianne Feinstein, she didn't vote for Roberts.
Mm-hmm.

I think that anyone the president sends up who will be acceptable to conservatives--if you take that as a given, that he is going to find someone who's acceptable to conservatives--is going to get a minimum of 22 no votes from Democrats, I think.
I mean, I don't see how they do any better than Roberts did.
That's how many voted against John Roberts.
Yes.
Yes.
So I don't see how the next one, given that it's the swing seat, it's the crucial seat, it's the balance of power on the court that's in the bal--at stake, how they get more Democrats.
And you had a bunch of Democratic interest groups who have been very quiet.
We have not heard from them through the whole Miers thing because they've been happily sitting on the sidelines watching this intramural fight.
They warned every Democrat, `OK, we didn't get as many votes as we wanted against Roberts.
But next time, we are counting on you to vote no. This is the big one.
And there's going to be tremendous pressure on Democrats to vote no.
David Savage, indeed, there was the opinion during the Roberts hearing that Democrats were keeping their powder dry; some of them perhaps voting for John Roberts while maybe holding their nose.
But at least to say, `Well, see, if the person's highly qualified, we can vote for him.
Next time around is the one that will matter.
Yes.

I think it's very easy to envision a scenario if President Bush were to do what some of our earlier speakers were saying and pick somebody who's very conservative and basically is on record as saying, `Roe vs. Wade was wrong, and I would overturn it,' you'd not only lose the 44 Democrats, the Republicans will say, `OK, we don't need the Democrats,' but you'd even be in danger of losing some Republicans like Arlen Specter...
The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Yes.
Olympia Snowe from Maine--there are several pro-choice Republicans, 'cause that's the real--I think if I were advising President Bush, that's the real danger.
It's not just losing the Democrats.
If you go too far right, you could then lose some Republicans and then have a situation where your nomination doesn't--your nominee doesn't get confirmed.
Who on the short list does not have a paper trail on Roe like that?
Who would avoid that problem on the short list?
This is it.
This is this is what we do.
We're here to protect our public lands and our valuable cultural sites, and that's why we're here.

Well, some of them have paper trails and beliefs that sound like John Roberts, that is that they're probably personally opposed to abortion, they think it's abominable or immoral, they've said things like that.
And they think that the Roe vs. Wade decision was wrongly decided, but they've never actually written that it should be overturned.
And so I'm not sure.
I think Mike Luttig would be close to somebody who thinks Roe was wrongly decided and should be overturned.
I think there are a few others that might.
Janice Rogers Brown is a fairly blunt person.
I think she would take that view.

So I have not researched all their records, but I think some of them, there would be the danger if you do exactly what some of the conservative groups want, `Give us a conservative with a conservative record,' you would be in danger of sending up somebody who may not be confirmed.
But there are conservatives on the short list who don't have that kind of black-and-white record on Roe that conservatives would like.
Yes, that's right.
I mean, so in other words, he does have people to choose from that at least wouldn't come in with bells clanging on Roe.

But even if somebody like Mike McConnell, who is very well regarded among academics and I think would be a pretty smart pick, there will be a lot of discussion in the hearings of saying, `Judge McConnell, you've said Roe was wrongly decided; it was a abominable decision.
We want to know what does that mean?
Are you now going to overturn it if you get on the Supreme Court?
So there would be a big focus on that.
From Democrats, yes.
From Democrats.
From Democrats, as opposed to with a stealth nominee where you get those questions from Republicans, and that makes it more uncomfortable.
Well, from Democrats, and as we saw in the Roberts' hearing, from the chairman, Arlen Specter...
From the chairman.
...of Pennsylvania, who's no small influence in the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings.
And, Mara, let me ask you finally--we're running out of time on this, but the president, as he looks ahead on this, three years left.
Is this the lame-duck session of the Bush presidency?

Well, you know, last week during the conservative--the height of the conservative revolt, I had conservatives tell me, `Isn't it ironic that conservatives, you know, turned George Bush into a lame duck faster than Democrats did?
Well, it could be.
I mean, he has to come back--and don't forget, it's not just Miers.
It's Katrina, it's Iraq, it's spending, it's all these other things, Social Security's dead.

What is--you know, he has to come out in February in the State of the Union address--or end of January--and lay out an agenda that's going to unify his base, appeal to the country and be able to get through Congress.
I don't know what that is.
If he can't do that, yes, he's officially a lame duck at that point.
Mara Liasson, thanks very much for being with us.
Mara Liasson is NPR's national political correspondent.
David Savage, Supreme Court reporter for the Los Angeles Times, we thank you for your time today, as well.
They were both kind enough to join us here in Studio 3A.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
You've been listening to special coverage from NPR News.
Let's look now at one of the toughest issues in politics, how to erase inequality in pay between women and men.
In today's workplace, women are just like men only cheaper, at least that's what the statistics say, with women earning 79 cents for every dollar a man makes.
But in Boston, women do a little better.
They make a few pennies more on the dollar.
Ibby Caputo reports on how the city of Boston is taking a novel approach to closing the pay gap.
On a weekday evening at the YWCA in Boston, volunteer Mariko Meier stands in front of a room full of women and tells them to...
Know your value.
Identify a target salary and benefits package.
Know your strategy and practice.
Meier is facilitating a salary negotiation workshop offered for free by the city of Boston.
It's targeted to women and is the city's latest attempt at closing the gender-wage gap.
Workshop participant Leah Press says she's talked with her friends about pay equity before, but she's never had the conversation in a larger group.

So far, I think my take-away tonight is really understanding what my value is, not being humble in a sense of devaluing myself, but realizing how much I add to my company and expecting that they take care of me for that.
Boston Mayor Marty Walsh says there's an economic advantage to teaching women to negotiate.

By increasing the amount of money that women have that will be spent on their families and spent on living and not having to cut back on certain areas, I mean, it makes a tremendous impact in the economy.
The project is scaled to have a big impact.
Boston aims to train 85,000 women how to negotiate their salaries over the next five years.
That's nearly half of the city's female workforce.
We decided, you know, let's go big or go home on this one.
Megan Costello is the executive director of Boston's Office of Women's Advancement.
She says legislation alone is not going to fix the gender-wage gap.
The question for us is, what's the cultural reason for why the wage gap is so persistent and so evident in every industry?
To answer this question, the city is reviewing wage data with employers.
It's also trying to empower women.
Part of the problem right now is women don't ask, right?
Right, sort of - research actually shows men don't ask either.
Hannah Riley Bowles is a senior lecturer at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government.
It is not the majority of men in most studies that are negotiating.
It's a minority of men and then it's an even smaller minority of women.
Boston's goal is to turn that minority into a majority.
But will teaching women to negotiate make a difference?
We're talking about the class that is emerging in the Muslim world.
They constitute people who are better off, who want new opportunities, participate in the global economy, and also want the political freedoms that go with it.
Those are the people who use the social media.
Those are the people that are inspiring the new language of politics in the Middle East.
How prominent were these capitalists or middle-class rising people in the demonstrations in Egypt?
They were very prominent.
They were prominent in actually instigating it, in mobilizing it, and then defining the way in which it asked for its political demands.
Wael Ghonim, the Google executive, this is the kind of person...
That's right.
We see him as a youthful technological-savvy person that we can identify with.
But Ghonim also represents the deep penetration of a major global multinational corporation in the form of Google into Egypt.
And how widespread is this middle class in some of the other countries that have seen demonstrations in recent weeks?
It is quite an uneven scene.
In other words, countries like Tunisia or Egypt have a very large middle class.
In Egypt, during the last years of the Mubarak period, because of the economic reforms, it actually began to feel empowered.
It is a big presence in Iran.
But in countries like Bahrain and Yemen or Libya, it's not as large or as influential.
I wonder if there's a bitter irony here.

If you're saying that Tunisia and Egypt are places where the middle class has grown very substantially - other places not so much - should we not expect too many more regimes to fall necessarily in the coming days and weeks?
